The Prambanan Temple Compounds are UNESCO World Heritage spots so that pretty much sums it up. It is a very beautiful place with big parks with lots of green and amazing hindu temples all over the place. You have to see it once in your lifetime !

Nice change of scenery. The temple is in pristine condition. The place is clean, have many restroom. Make sure to bring umbrella or a hat and also water. The walk to the temple is a little bit further from the food stand. The temple stair is very steep and narrow, so be careful.

It's possible to reduce the cost by being a student, having an Indonesian work visa or by getting a combo ticket with Borobudur (But you'll have to go to this temple the next day)

It's the place which you must go if you're have any interest in historical building. This place is large, this place has some souvenir market and food market of course. This place are popular in Indonesia, so if you planned going here it will better if you go here not in vacation time. This place is hot, wearing a cap or umbrella may helping to avoid that. You will find a unique experience if you go here (that's happened to me, so I only guess about this). There's a night show which tells the story about this place too, I recommend to go here at night if you want to see it (I don't see it when I go here). This was also on our bucket list and we were delighted to be able to visit this place.  

The temple buildings are spread across a large compound and they have restored around five buildings.  They are truly impressive and you cannot help but have a sense of awe and wonder.  There are beautiful carvings and statues inside, and the steps are pretty manageable.

On the day that we visited, there were a group of tourism students who provided a free short tour.

There is a museum onsite, and also photo ops like swings and riding a bike across a wire.

If you are planning to visit Borobudur, you should get the combined ticket, which gives you a discount.

How many Times I have been here, this place is still majestic..amazing. I like the park around and how organized the place is. If you happen to visit Indonesia, don't miss this out! After the visit, you will pass some street vendors who sell good local traditional food. You should try some!

Prambanan Temple complex is an impressive ancient Hindu religion temple located in the Special Region of Jogjakarta. It a must visit place if you are first time visiting Jogjakarta and wants to learn about the history of religion and old kingdom of Java. 

This is a huge temple complex therefore, please plan to spend time at least half a day there. The temple located a little bit far from the entrance therefore, be prepare to walk a distance there. Please bring umbrella if the weather forecast a rain because shelter is hard to find. Or otherwise you'll be wet running to the exit area.

If you want less crowd, please come during the weekdays and avoid local public holidays. Anyhow, this is a must visit place if you in Jogjakarta no matter you are a backpacker or with family.

The largest hindu temple complex in Indonesia located in Jogjakarta, the heart of Java, built around 9th or 10th century. From a distance the complex look so elegant and when you get closer it makes you breathless to see how huge and magnificent those temples are! for those who have never been to Jogja, put Prambanan Temple Complex in your bucket list. there will be no regrets when you get there ??

The most popular temple in Jogyarkarta. Throngs of locals flood the temples on the Sunday we were there and as a foreigner get ready to be bombarded with requests for photos. However the place is very vast, the people are nice, you get a complimentary drink for your entry ticket and you can go to the furthest temple ( sewu temple) if you wanna get great unspoilt pictures ??

First is that in order to exit you have to pass through about 3.5million shops, there is no other way. The temple is awe inspiring, as well as the various idols dating back to the 9th century AD. The conventions in the idols are very similar to those in India (except that the Ganesha doesnt have a pet mouse ). 
The Ramayana ballet is fabulous and worth seeing.
This is one of beautiful tample in indonesia ?

Really enjoyed Prambanan temple and Id recommend it to anyone.

We came here at 3pm during November and found that it was a decent time of day to come. The temperature wasnt too hot and there wasnt too many people around. It was 350,000 rupiah for entry which personally I find too expensive, so it loses a star.

The temple is a 5 minute walk away from the entrance gates. When we arrived in the temple area we were approached by two school girls who offered to give us a free guided tour. If youre offered I would highly recommend it. Theyre quite knowledgeable and it gives them an opportunity to practise their English. They only guide you for around 15 minutes so you have an opportunity to explore the rest of the temple by yourself. 

Overall the experience was great. The shrines are really interesting and with a guide the experience is engaging.

really expensive tickets. Very beautiful temple complex. The temples are higher than youd think. You truly appreciate their size only when you are standing right next to them. You can walk to the other edge of the area to see the other temple complexes. They have some sort of zoo and an archery range too. The museums give basic information
One of the best destination in Yogyakarta,, I went there n its so beautiful. Recommended.. Enter fee 50.000 for adult ????
Iconic place! Worth to visit! There will be some annual festival conducted in Prambanan Temple such as Festival Payung Indonesia.

Great place to visit , be sure to pack a umbrella for the sun can get quite hot , also plenty of water to cool off. Great views indeed well worth the trip . Theres also some great places to get coffee at , guys take extra care to make it just right . Only issue when exit the temple they direct u down and around the back side of the area , so be ready to walk .

Wonderful place to visit as it is full of culture and architectural wonders. You would wonder how the people of the past were able to built this marvels.  It is a Hindu temple so expect to see statues of Gods like shiva. The entrance fee was 33,000 per adult and it is cheaper for students and children. Try to come during the early morning as it is cooler. I came at 1pm and the weather was punishing as there are no shelter.

Built in the 10th century, this is the largest temple compound dedicated to Shiva in Indonesia. Rising above the centre of the last of these concentric squares are three temples decorated with reliefs illustrating the epic of the Ramayana, dedicated to the three great Hindu divinities (Shiva, Vishnu and Brahma) and three temples dedicated to the animals who serve them. 
You can rent a local tourguide for some explain. 
In this place,  we must guard our speech,  don't speek harshly and dirty.  Because this is a holy place.

Prambanan or Rara Jonggrang (Javanese: ?????????, romanized: Rara Jonggrang) is a 9th-century Hindu temple compound in Special Region of Yogyakarta, Indonesia, dedicated to the Trim?rti, the expression of God as the Creator (Brahma), the Preserver (Vishnu) and the Transformer (Shiva). The temple compound is located approximately 17 kilometres (11 mi) northeast of the city of Yogyakarta on the boundary between Central Java and Yogyakarta provinces.

Clean and well maintained complex. It was very interesting to walk through. It can get hot and crowded as the day progresses so try to visit early morning or the late afternoon. Also, if youre a westerner, prepare to take a ton of photos with other friendly and respectful visitors!!
Beautiful temple. Rivals that of some of the more illustrious in South East Asia - truly magnificent
one of the must visit is Prambanan Temple, its good have seen the temple , a lot of people around and good view.

A must in your stay in Java. Its a little bit packed of tourists. The architecture and the history behind this temple is amazing. Also, if you are lucky some Javanese school come there to learn english. They will ask you to be your guide to improve their English and their knowledge for free. Some of the locals would love to take a picture with you!

Built in the 10th century, this is the largest temple compound dedicated to Shiva in Indonesia. Rising above the centre of the last of these concentric squares are three temples decorated with reliefs illustrating the epic of the Ramayana, dedicated to the three great Hindu divinities (Shiva, Vishnu and Brahma) and three temples dedicated to the animals who serve them.

Very cool temple compound. It was an even better experience than Borobudur. Theres so many things to see and you can choose your own mode of transport from walking, buggy, cycling and so on. I had fun walking through the ancient ruins and visiting all the different Temples and intricate structure from the past.

The place is great and probably everything you expect it to be, however, if you are a foreigner you have to go through a separate entrance where the price is much much higher (many times more) than it is for people from Indonesia. Its roughly £20 to enter as a foriegner, which isn't that bad in the grand scheme of things but will definitely come as a shock if you've been here a while and experienced how much stuff normally costs. All being said and done if it goes to keeping up the place up it's all good, just feels wrong entering a temple like its an airport arrivals terminal.

Prambanan or Rara Jonggrang (Javanese: ?????????, romanized: Rara Jonggrang) is a 9th-century Hindu temple compound in Special Region of Yogyakarta, Indonesia, dedicated to the Trim?rti, the expression of God as the Creator (Brahma), the Preserver (Vishnu) and the Transformer (Shiva). The temple compound is located approximately 17 kilometres (11 mi) northeast of the city of Yogyakarta on the boundary between Central Java and Yogyakarta provinces.

The temple compound, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, is the largest Hindu temple site in Indonesia and the second-largest in Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its tall and pointed architecture, typical of Hindu architecture, and by the towering 47-metre-high (154 ft) central building inside a large complex of individual temples. Prambanan attracts many visitors from around the world

This temple is not worth the price. Theres not much to see and poorly maintained. Staff here were very very rude. One of the security guards insisted that I cannot enter the property other than the main gate, while there were literally people walking besides me talking in Indonesian. Just like that, they try to rip you off the moment they notice youre a foreigner.

Prambanan temple is the largest hindu temple of ancient Java and it is the largest hindu temple site in Indonesia and the second largest in south east Asia. The first building was completed in the mid-9th century. 
Balinese and Javanese Hindu communities in Yogyakarta and Central Java revived their practices of annually performing their sacred ceremonies in Prambanan, such as Galungan, Tawur Kesanga, and Nyepi.
You can watch some traditional javanese dance that has been performed every full moon night in here. Or try to watch the ballet of traditional ramayana epic at night. It's really worth it .

Best choice for me of the three most-famous temples in Yogyakarta. Expect to pay like $25. Its expensive, but well, its like it is. Inside the whole area, you can find the main one, but you can take a short walk (15) and you will enjoy more places also outstanding like the really first one. Take your student card if youre one.
